unnormalised: ## Kachra Chronicles: Let's Talk Waste Management, Yaar!
normalised: Kachra Chronicles: Let's Talk Waste Management, Yaar!

unnormalised: Hey everyone! Ever tripped over a pile of garbage near the corner of your street, or seen overflowing bins outside a wedding hall? Yeah, me too. It's a common sight in India, and it brings us to a not-so-glamorous but super important topic: waste management.
normalised: Hey everyone! Ever tripped over a pile of garbage near the corner of your street, or seen overflowing bins outside a wedding hall? Yeah, me too. It's a common sight in India, and it brings us to a not-so-glamorous but super important topic: waste management.

unnormalised: Think about all the chai we drink in those kulhads, the banana peels after a quick snack, the plastic wrappers from our favorite Kurkure… where does it all go? A lot of it unfortunately ends up polluting our land and rivers like the Ganga. That’s not cool, guys.
normalised: Think about all the chai we drink in those kulhads, the banana peels after a quick snack, the plastic wrappers from our favorite Kurkure… where does it all go? A lot of it unfortunately ends up polluting our land and rivers like the Ganga. That’s not cool, guys.

unnormalised: Waste management is essentially how we collect, treat, and dispose of our garbage. Ideally, it involves reducing waste at the source, reusing what we can, and recycling everything else possible. Remember that Swachh Bharat Abhiyan campaign? It's a massive effort aimed at improving sanitation and cleanliness across the country, and waste management is a huge part of that.

unnormalised: Think about your local sabziwala in Chandni Chowk. All that vegetable waste could be composted! Or the waste paper from that old NCERT textbook from Class 8… it can be recycled! The Municipal Corporation of Delhi is trying to implement better waste segregation, but we, as citizens, need to do our part.

unnormalised: Did you know that some innovative folks are turning plastic waste into roads? Pretty awesome, right? Institutions like IIT-Delhi are also working on developing new waste management technologies.

unnormalised: We all generate waste, but we can also all be part of the solution. Simple things like carrying our own cloth bags when we go shopping (instead of accepting those flimsy plastic ones) can make a huge difference. And segregating our waste into wet and dry categories, like my grandmother always insisted, is crucial.

unnormalised: Let's all try to be more mindful of our waste habits. Start small, maybe by taking a pledge on 02/10/2024, Gandhi Jayanti, to reduce your plastic consumption or by volunteering at a local cleanup drive at 10:00 AM on 15/01/2025. Remember, even small changes add up. And let’s hold our local municipalities accountable for proper waste collection and disposal as per the guidelines set on 26/01/1950.
